Items.Title: Roll Call
Invocation
Items.AgendaNote:
Delivered by: Rev. Dr. LaKeesha Walrond, Executive Pastor, First Corinthian Baptist Church, 1912 Adam Clayton Powell Jr. Blvd, New York, N.Y. 10026.

Motion to spread the invocation in full upon the record by Council Member Dickens.
Items.MinutesNote:
The Invocation was delivered by:  Dr. LaKeesha Walrond, Executive Pastor, First Corinthian Baptist Church, 1912 Adam Clayton Powell, Jr. Blvd., New York, N.Y. 10026..



Council Member Dickens moved to spread the Invocation in full upon the Record.

Items.Title: Adoption of Minutes

Items.MinutesNote: At this point, Council Member Reyna moved that the Minutes of the Stated Meeting of February 29, 2012 be adopted as printed.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass, and the Governor to sign, the New York Dream Act, which would grant certain benefits to eligible undocumented immigrants.
Items.AgendaNote: Amended and Adopted by the Committee on Immigration
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item:  Council Members Ignizio, Nelson and Oddo.



The following 4 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item:  Council Members Gentile, Halloran, Ulrich and Vallone, Jr.

Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: New York Dream Act

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign legislation establishing the New York DREAM fund commission, which will advance the educational opportunities of children of immigrants through scholarship programs for higher education.
Items.AgendaNote: Adopted by the Committee on Immigration
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 3 Council Members formally voted against this item:  Council Members Ignizio, Nelson, and Oddo.



The following 4 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item:  Council Members Gentile, Halloran, Ulrich, and Vallone, Jr.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Establishing the New York DREAM fund commission.

Resolution approving with modifications the decision of the City Planning Commission on ULURP No. C 120029 ZSM (L.U. No. 559), for the grant of special permits pursuant to Section 74-743(a)(1) - to allow the distribution of required open space under the applicable district regulations without regard for zoning lot lines; Section 74-743(a)(2) - to allow the location of buildings without regard for the height and setback requirements of Sections 23-632 and 33-432, the rear yard setback requirements of Section 23-663, and the inner court recess requirements of Section 23-843; and Section 74-743(a)(4) - to allow the maximum floor area ratio permitted pursuant to Section 23-142 for the applicable district without regard for the height factor or open space ratio requirements; in connection with a proposed mixed use development on property located at 133-147 West 11th Street (Block 607, Lot 1 and Block 617, Lot 1) in R8, C6-2 and C2-7 Districts, Borough of Manhattan.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Roll Call.

INTRODUCTION AND READING OF BILLS
A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the provision and posting of safety information for motor coach passengers.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Provision and posting of safety information for motor coach passengers.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting discrimination based on an individual’s unemployment.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting discrimination based on an individual’s unemployment.

Items.Title: Resolution authorizing franchises for cable television services.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Lower Manhattan Redevelopment
Items.MatterName: Authorizing franchises for cable television services. (20125458 GFY)

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the New York City Police Department to report noise complaints on a quarterly basis.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Requiring the NYPD to report noise complaints on a quarterly basis.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the Commissioner/Chief Executive Officer of New York State Homes and Community Renewal to amend the Rent Stabilization Code to disallow “preferential rents” that are not for the duration of the tenancy.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Amend the Rent Stabilization Code to disallow “preferential rents” that are not for the duration of the tenancy.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to regularly review the use and condition of transportable classrooms and to limit the amount of time that transportable classrooms are used in New York City public schools.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Dept of Education to regularly review the use and condition of transportable classrooms and to limit the amount of time that transportable classrooms are used in NYC public schools.

Items.Title: Resolution calling for further improvement in the consideration of health impacts in the Administration’s decision-making relating to real estate development projects, plans, and policies, specifically by utilizing health impact assessments and by increased collaboration between the Department of City Planning, the Economic Development Corporation, and the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Economic Development
Items.MatterName: Improvement in the consideration of health impacts in the Administration’s decision-making relating to real estate development projects, plans, and policies.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to extending whistleblower protection for officers and employees of city contractors and subcontractors.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Extending whistleblower protection for officers and employees of city contractors and subcontractors.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring certain information on notices of violation issued to food vendors.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Consumer Affairs
Items.MatterName: Requiring certain information on notices of violation issued to food vendors.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to the receipt of mail by city agencies.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Receipt of mail by city agencies.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to prohibit family day care, group family day care, school age child care and group child care programs and services from using rodenticides due to the dangers of exposure to young children, and the Department of Environmental Conservation to recommend nontoxic alternatives.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Prohibit family day care, group family day care, school age child care and group child care programs and services from using rodenticides due to the dangers of exposure to young children, and the Dept of Environmental Conservation to recommend nontoxic al

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York City Department of Education to implement specific protocols so that the New York City Department of Education will coordinate more formally with the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene and the New York City Administration for Children’s Services in order to properly diagnose children with developmental or learning disabilities.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Dept of Education to implement specific protocols so that the NYC Dept of Education will coordinate more formally with the NYC Dept of Health and Mental Hygiene and the NYC Administration for Children’s Services in order to properly diagnose children with

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress to pass and the President to sign the States' Medical Marijuana Patient Protection Act, which seeks to reclassify marijuana as other than a Schedule I or Schedule II substance.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: States' Medical Marijuana Patient Protection Act.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to revoking a food vending license for certain violations.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Revoking a food vending license for certain violations.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to air quality monitoring for certain construction projects.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Environmental Protection
Items.MatterName: Air quality monitoring for certain construction projects.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the reporting and publication online of certain information related to outdoor signs.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring the reporting and publication online of certain information related to outdoor signs.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to creating additional penalties for illegal outdoor signs.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Creating additional penalties for illegal outdoor signs.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to requiring the department of buildings to conduct semiannual inspections of outdoor signs.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Housing and Buildings
Items.MatterName: Requiring the department of buildings to conduct semiannual inspections of outdoor signs.

Items.Title: Resolution condemning the senseless shooting of Trayvon Martin and the inadequate investigation that followed, expressing deep sympathy for the Martin family, and calling for a full and impartial investigation holding those responsible to account as well as an examination of “Stand Your Ground” laws nationwide and the role they play in the spread of illegal guns on New York City’s streets.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MatterName: Condemning the senseless shooting of Trayvon Martin and the inadequate investigation that followed.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the U.S. Department of Homeland Security to reverse its position that the Secure Communities program will be activated nationally by 2013, and to respect states like New York that have taken actions to rescind their participation in this program.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Immigration
Items.MatterName: U.S. Department of Homeland Security to reverse its position that the Secure Communities program will be activated nationally by 2013.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to permissible parking in front of private driveways.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Permissible parking in front of private driveways.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to amend the State Education Law, in relation to mayoral control of the New York City public school system, by requiring that the respective Community Education Council approve a co-location or school closure/phase-out proposal before it may be presented for a vote by the Panel for Educational Policy.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Education
Items.MatterName: Requiring that the respective Community Education Council approve a co-location or school closure/phase-out proposal before it may be presented for a vote by the Panel for Educational Policy.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign legislation that would add an excise tax on sugar sweetened beverages.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Add an excise tax on sugar sweetened beverages.

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the United States Food and Drug Administration to require warning labels on sugar sweetened beverages.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Require warning labels on sugar sweetened beverages.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the New York city charter, in relation to the democratic election of the New York City police commissioner.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Governmental Operations
Items.MatterName: Democratic election of the New York City police commissioner.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Congress to pass H.R. 3618/S.1670, the End Racial Profiling Act of 2011.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety
Items.MatterName: Congress to pass H.R. 3618/S.1670, the End Racial Profiling Act of 2011.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to posting of truck route road conditions by the department of transportation.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Transportation
Items.MatterName: Posting of truck route road conditions by the department of transportation.

Items.Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to prohibiting the manufacture and sale of products containing synthetic cannabinoid.
Items.ActionText: This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Prohibiting the manufacture and sale of products containing synthetic cannabinoid.

Items.Title: Resolution calling on the United States Senate to pass and the President to sign the Dangerous Synthetic Drug Control Act of 2011, which would amend the Controlled Substances Act by banning synthetic cannabinoids commonly used in herbal incense.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Health
Items.MatterName: Dangerous Synthetic Drug Control Act of 2011

Items.Title: Resolution calling upon the New York State Legislature to pass and the Governor to sign the Veterans Cemetery Bill (A.1386A/S.5381A), legislation that would provide for the establishment of a State veterans cemetery in New York.
Items.ActionText: This Resolution was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Veterans
Items.MatterName: Veterans Cemetery Bill (A.1386A/S.5381A)

Items.Title: Resolution condemning the senseless shooting of Trayvon Martin and the inadequate investigation that followed, expressing deep sympathy for the Martin family, and calling for a full and impartial investigation holding those responsible to account as well as an examination of “Stand Your Ground” laws nationwide and the role they play in the spread of illegal guns on New York City’s streets.
Items.AgendaNote: Preconsidered - Adopted by the Committee on Civil Rights
Items.MinutesNote:
Pursuant to Rule 8.50 of the Council, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) called for a voice vote.  Hearing those in favor, the President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie) declared the Resolution to be adopted.



The following 5 Council Members formally abstained to vote on this item:  Council Members Halloran, Ignizio, Ulrich, Vallone, Jr. and Oddo.



Adopted by the Council by voice-vote.
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Resolution be Approved, by Council approved by Voice Vote.
Items.MatterName: Condemning the senseless shooting of Trayvon Martin and the inadequate investigation that followed.

Items.MinutesNote: The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie)
The presence of a quorum was announced by The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie).

Items.MinutesNote: At this point the Speaker (Council Member Quinn) made the following annoucements:

Whereupon on motion of the Speaker (Council Member Quinn), the President Pro Temore (Council Member Comrie) adjourned to meet again on Wednesday, April 18, 2012.



MICHAEL M. McSWEENEY, City Clerk

Clerk of the Council
The President Pro Tempore (Council Member Comrie)  put the question whether the Council would agree with and adopt such reports, which were decided in the affirmative by the following vote:

The following files were removed from the General Order Calendar and voted separately:



INT 490-A   47-2-1 (Override Vote) (Negative: CMs Garodnick, Koppell; Abstention: Wills)
 
INT 18-A  46-4-0 (Negative: CMs Halloran, Ignizio, Vallone Jr, and Oddo)
 
LU 559 & Res 1288 through LU 563 & Res 1292:  49-1-0 (Negative: CM Barron)
 
M 749 & Res 1285, M 750 & Res 1286: 47-0-3 (Abstention: CMs Barron, Fidler and Vacca)



See files for individual votes.



Notwithstanding the objection of the Mayor, both Int No. 490-A (by a vote of 47-2-1) and Int No. 546-A (by a vote of 50-0-0) were adopted by the Council and thereby enacted into law.

Items.Title: Application no. 20125298 TCM, pursuant to §20-226 of the Administrative Code of the City of New York, concerning the petition of Il Commendatore Restaurant Inc.,  d.b.a Casa Bella, to continue to maintain and operate an unenclosed sidewalk café located at 127 Mulberry Street, Borough of Manhattan, Council District no.1.  This application is subject to review and action by the Land Use Committee only if called-up by vote of the Council pursuant to Rule 11.20b of the Council and §20-226(g) of the New York City Administrative Code.
Items.MinutesNote: Filed Pursuant to a Letter of Withdrawal
Items.ActionText: A motion was made that this Land Use Application be Filed, by Council approved by Consent Roll Call.
Items.MatterName: Sidewalk café, 127 Mulberry St, Manhattan (20125298 TCM)

Items.Title: Passed The Consent Agenda
